docs.lead_paragraph: The first signs that Dr. Barbara Zucker-Pinchoff's life was about to come apart were small and seemingly innocuous. As she lay on an operating table at New York University Medical Center in 1988, preparing for the birth of her second child by Caesarean section, her nose began to itch. She felt terribly congested, her hands started to swell and her face turned beet red. She told her husband she thought she was allergic to the hospital's air-conditioning system.

headline.main: A Rise in Allergies to Latex Threatens Medical Workers

docs.abstract: More than 10 percent of country's health care workers are allergic to latex, allergy that was almost unheard of decade ago; illness affects roughly 3 percent of general population; at least 30 people have died of latex-related illnesses in last decade; sharp rise in reported allergies stems from sevenfold increase in use of latex gloves since 1987, when Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advised health care workers to wear them to protect against infection from HIV; allergy is unpredictable, and can be devastating; in some people allergies build up slowly through years; most troublesome is that those who are allergic to latex often get much sicker when they seek treatment because doctors' offices and hospitals, where air is thick with latex powder, are most dangerous places; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I write in response to Kevin J. Williams's Soapbox (''Family Fair,'' Feb. 28) about the need for equality regardless of gender or sexual orientation. New Jersey law prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation. Yet the state doesn't recognize same-gender marriages, so lesbians and gay men have no opportunity to gain domestic partner health benefits.

headline.main: Domestic Partner Coverage Is Fair and Inexpensive

docs.abstract: Fern Goodheart letter responds to Kevin J Williams' February 28 Soapbox essay, holds cost of extending benefits to domestic partners is low for employers and would not compromise New Jersey's fiscal standing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Dorothy Green of Bridgeport totalled her car in 1996, she decided not to replace it. She notified her insurance company but the company continued to automatically deduct car insurance premiums from her paycheck -- for more than 18 months. Ms. Green said she was unable to resolve the problem herself, so she contacted the Connecticut Insurance Department, which had the company, Metropolitan Life, Auto and Home, cancel the policy retroactively and reimburse her more than $3,000.
docs.abstract: Article on success of Connecticut Insurance Department in resolving consumer complaints (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton put Republicans on the defensive when he proposed to tap most of the budget surplus in the next 15 years to shore up Social Security and pay down the national debt, not to cut taxes as they wanted. Most voter surveys show that Americans embrace Mr. Clinton's choice. Now, in their first formal response to the President's budget, the Republicans have tried to outdo him by setting aside even more money for Social Security than Mr. Clinton proposed. They would also defer their tax cuts for at least two years. Their new approach is a step in the right direction. But it has many flaws, including unacceptable cuts in Medicare and other domestic spending. The Republican move reflects a clear recognition that the party's lawmakers cannot be seen as less than zealous about protecting Social Security. At present, the system generates a surplus. But while economists disagree on the timing, it will plunge into insolvency as baby boomers retire. For many years the Social Security surplus has been used to pay for other spending in the budget, and the Republicans now say they want to end that practice right away. The problem with such a step is that, as some Republicans have acknowledged, it would require steep budget cuts next year. The Republicans have already said they want spending increases in defense and some education programs, so the cuts would have to come in myriad other programs that they have not yet specified.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that Pres Clinton put Republicans on defensive when he proposed to tap most of budget surplus in next 15 years to shore up Social Security and pay down national debt, not to cut taxes as they wanted; notes that most voter surveys show that Americans embrace Clinton's choice; maintains that Republicans, in their first formal response to Clinton's budget, have tried to outdo him by setting aside even more money for Social Security than Clinton proposed; notes that they would also defer their tax cuts for at least two years; holds that their new approach is step in right direction, but it has many flaws, including unacceptable cuts in Medicare and other domestic spending

docs.lead_paragraph: IN a storefront soup kitchen on Front Street in Hempstead, the Interfaith Nutrition Network serves 200 meals a day, five days a week, to children and adults from the vicinity. The charitable network runs 19 such sites in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. But every Monday afternoon, the Hempstead site closes a half-hour early. Lunch tables are moved out of the way, replaced by portable examining tables and medical carts surrounded by privacy curtains. In 30 minutes the transformation is complete, and the soup kitchen has become a clinic.

headline.main: On the Menu Today: Health Care

docs.abstract: Article on Rotacare, collaborative project of Interfaith Nutrition Network soup kitchen in Hempstead, Long Island, and Rotary Club which provides weekly free health care for those lacking medical insurance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY morning, Abraham Landau commutes from White Plains on the 8:26 train to his job as sales manager for Performing Arts magazine in the Graybar Building over Grand Central Terminal. His days are so busy, he sometimes has to rush to make the 4:47 home. ''It's an exciting job, a lot of fun,'' Mr. Landau said. ''I look forward to going to the office. In the 18 months I've been there I've never been late or taken a sick day.''

headline.main: Those Who Retire to Work or Volunteer

docs.abstract: Article on growing number of retired workers who are relinquishing volunteer or part-time positions to take full-time jobs as pool of younger workers diminishes; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HALF the babies born in New York City go home from the hospital to families with incomes below the poverty level. Something like 10 million children in this country lack health insurance. And, on average, American children spend 1,500 hours a year watching television, compared with just 900 in the classroom. But never mind all that. As a result of a public outcry, Calvin Klein Inc. has canceled its new advertising campaign -- including a controversial billboard in Manhattan's Times Square -- for a line of children's underwear. The ads showed children actually wearing the underwear, a fact that astonished and appalled conservative groups, psychologists and others.
docs.abstract: Daniel Akst The Culture of Money column deplores failure of critics of Calvin Klein Inc's advertising drive for children's underwear line to protest everyday television programming and advertising that subject young viewers to violence and hucksterism; photo (M)g

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Feb. 28 Week in Review article on managed care's ''other problem'' left out an important reason why the denial rate for care claims may be low. Denying claims can be a costly endeavor. It is relatively easy to deny the high-profile claims for experimental treatments because they are few and far between, lend themselves to individual scrutiny, and can be done before the treatment.
docs.abstract: Abigail Sarokin letter on Feb 28 article holds denial rate for managed health care claims may be low because denial process is costly (S)0

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Thomas C. Matzzie graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1997 with a degree in economics, he decided not to follow many of his classmates into high-paying careers on Wall Street or elsewhere. Instead, he took a lower-paying job, as a policy analyst at the Institute for America's Future, a liberal research organization in Washington. Mr. Matzzie, 23, who grew up near Pittsburgh, credits Medicare -- of all things -- with giving him the chance to follow his interests rather than chase a big salary. ''When I was a senior in high school, my grandmother -- who has since died -- became very ill,'' he recalled. ''Medicare was there and helped pay the expenses that would otherwise have bankrupted our family. Because of Medicare I was able to go on to college and then have the freedom to do nonprofit work that pays less, because I know that the burden of taking care of my parents will be a lot less with Medicare.''
docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on debate over Medicare's future; cites need to remind forgetful public that program was founded in part to ease burden on children of their parents' illnesses; opposes proposal to let affluent shop for private insurance; drawing (M)0

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I found it interesting to read Governor Whitman's quotation on the importance of ''self-identity'' in the cover article ''What's Love Got to Do With It?'' (cover, Feb. 14). Is this the same Governor who supports legislation prohibiting same-sex legal unions between such responsible people as Michael Galluccio and John Holden-Galluccio, mentioned in the same article? I wonder why she is so threatened by the thought of giving them and their children the same inheritance tax benefits and so on that she enjoys in her marriage. I'm sure Michael and Jon's ''self-identity'' is largely defined by the loving relationship of their family. VINCENT TAFILOWSKI New Hope, Pa.

headline.main: Domestic Partner Coverage Is Fair and Inexpensive
